user: This project is a complete two-way voice assistant built using Murf Falcon Text-to-Speech, browser speech recognition, and a Python Flask backend. The frontend listens to user speech, converts it to text, sends it to the backend, receives an audio reply generated by Murf TTS, and plays it back with a clean chat-style UI. Users can choose voices, speaking styles, speed, and pitch. The backend includes logic generation, TTS processing, and API handling. The system supports real-time conversations and optional short-term memory to maintain context.

user: This project is a fully functional two-way Voice Assistant built using Murf Falcon TTS, browser-based Speech Recognition (ASR), and a Python Flask backend. Its purpose is to demonstrate a complete voice interaction pipeline, where the system can:  Listen to the user  Convert speech into text  Generate a reply using custom logic  Speak that reply using Murf Falcon TTS  Maintain a fluid, real-time conversation  The result is an interactive voice-based AI system with customizable settings and continuous dialogue.   To build a voice-enabled conversational prototype that supports:  Real-time speech-to-text  Automated text reply generation  High-quality Murf Falcon text-to-speech  Continuous two-way communication  Voice personality customization  Adjustable audio characteristics  Memory of previous user inputs  This matches the requirement: “Build a working voice agent prototype using Murf Falcon TTS API with ASR for two-way conversational interaction.”
assistant: So you've built a fully functional voice assistant prototype that meets the requirements, with features like real-time conversation, customizable voices, and memory of previous inputs - what's the next step or challenge you're facing with this project?

user: Architecture Summary: The frontend records speech, converts it to text using the Web Speech API, and sends it to the backend. The backend generates a reply, converts the reply to audio using Murf Falcon TTS, and sends the audio file back. The frontend plays the audio reply and displays the text in a conversation-style UI. Voice selection, style settings, pitch, and speed controls are also part of the system.
assistant: That's a great summary of the architecture. So, the Web Speech API handles the speech-to-text conversion on the frontend, and Murf Falcon TTS handles the text-to-speech conversion on the backend, allowing for a seamless conversation experience. Is there anything specific you'd like to add or change in this architecture?
